title: Bryon Butler
text:
Ewart Bryon Butler (5 June 1934 – 26 April 2001) was an <a href="England">English</a> writer and broadcaster, best known as the <a href="BBC">BBC</a>'s <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> correspondent from 1968 to 1991.
He was born in <a href="Taunton">Taunton</a>, <a href="Somerset">Somerset</a> and educated at <a href="Taunton%20School">Taunton School</a>. After working for a number of regional <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a>s, he joined the "<a href="News%20Chronicle">News Chronicle</a>" shortly before its closure in 1960, soon moving to "<a href="The%20Daily%20Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a>". Around this time, he also started reporting football matches for the BBC, and in 1968 became a radio commentator and the corporation's football correspondent. He was well known for his crisp, eloquent, precise style, with a distinctive <a href="West%20Country">West Country</a> undertone to his voice. Although he often did not actually commentate on the very big occasions, frequently taking a side role as summariser (in earlier years) or presenter or reporter (in later years), he commentated on a number of <a href="Football%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> finals, as well as the famous quarter-final between <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> and <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina</a> in 1986. He frequently worked alongside <a href="Maurice%20Edelston">Maurice Edelston</a>, <a href="Peter%20Jones%20%28broadcaster%29">Peter Jones</a>, <a href="Alan%20Parry">Alan Parry</a> and, latterly, <a href="Alan%20Green%20%28broadcaster%29">Alan Green</a> and <a href="Mike%20Ingham">Mike Ingham</a>.
He wrote or co-wrote a number of football books and also wrote for the "Daily Telegraph" on <a href="cricket">cricket</a>. In 1991, he retired as the BBC's football correspondent to concentrate on his writing career. He also gave up commentary around this time.
On his death in 2001, he was widely mourned as a representative of a bygone era of sports broadcasting, arguably less brash and more eloquent than the present.
